titleStmt.title: The petition and articles exhibited in Parliament against Dr. Fvller, deane of Ely and vicar of S. Giles Cripple-gate with the petition exhibited in Parliament against Timothy Hutton, curate of the said parish by the parishioners of Saint Giles : wherein are discovered many popish innovations and disservice to the church and placing such to officiate who preferre the play-house and the taverne before the performance of their office in the church, as may appeare by the said articles.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE PETITION AND ARTICLES EXHIBITED IN PARLIAMENT Again≈øt Dr FVLLER, DEANE OF ELY, AND Vicar of S. Giles Cripple-gate. WITH THE PETITION Exhibited in Parliament again≈øt Timothy Hutton, Curate of the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, By the Pari≈øhioners of Saint Giles.

Wherein are di≈øcovered many Popi≈øh Innovations, and di≈ø≈øervice to the Church, and placing ≈øuch to officiate, who preferre the Play-hou≈øe and the Taverns before the performance of their Office in the Church, as may appeare by the ≈øaid Articles.

div.head: TO THE HONOVRABLE THE Knights. Citizens‚ñ™ and Burge≈ø≈øes, Nowa≈ø≈øembled in PARLIAMENT.
The humble Petition of divers of the Pari≈øhioners of St. Giles Cripple-gato, London.
div.p: THat the ≈øaid Pari≈øh is very great, con≈øi≈øting of 40000 ≈øoules, or thereabouts, having no con≈øtant Preaching Mini≈øter among≈øt them, although the Living be worth ≈øeven hundred pounds, per annum, to the pre≈øent incumbent William Fuller Dr. in Divinity, who being a Popi≈øh Innovator, broacheth very pernitious &c dangerous Doctrines, imployeth to officiate for him, men ≈øcandalous in life, & by a ≈øelected ve≈øtry fit for his turne, doth grievou≈øly oppre≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid Pari≈øhioners: as will further appeare by the Schedule of Articles hereunto annexed.

May it therefore plea≈øe this Honourable Hou≈øe, to take into con≈øideration the≈øe Premi≈øes, vvith the ≈øeverall Articles annexed, and to grant ≈øuch reliefe herein, as to your great vvi≈øedomes ≈øhall ≈øeeme mo≈øt meet.

div.head: THE ARTICLES EXHIBITED In Parliament again≈øt Dr. Fuller ∆≤icar of St. Giles Cripple-Gate.
div.p: THe ≈øaid Dr. Fuller in the Petition before mentioned, hath Pluralities of livings, and thereby is a Non-Re≈øident, allowing no Sermons on the Lords day in the afternoone for many moneths together, and if any at all, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne but ≈øcandalous livers have u≈øually ≈øupplye ‚Ä¢ the place.

2. He u≈øeth ≈øuper≈øtitious cringing and bowing to the Communion table, and the name Ie≈øus, holding ≈øuch a venerable e≈øteeme of the Ray los about the Table; that he hath cau≈øed divers per≈øons for re≈øting thereon in Sermon time, to bee violently thru≈øt out of the church, to the great di≈øturbance of the Congregation, but ≈ølubbereth over the Sacrament of Bapti≈øme when the Congregation is appointed to ≈øing a p≈øalme: ≈øo that they cannot mind the duty to joyne with them in prayer.

3. He hath cau≈øed the new Canons with the Oath to be publi≈øhed in our church, urging obedience
thereunto, ≈øaying, we have been faine to e≈øtabli≈øh the Kings regall power, and wee have taken great paines to e≈øtabli≈øh this for you, hee being then a convocation man.

4 He hath publi≈øhed in the pulpit, that all our e≈øtates are at the Kings di≈øpo≈øing, and that th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e is no difference betweene our church of England, and the church of Rome, in matter of ≈øub≈øtance, but in circum≈øtance onely, which might ea≈øily bee reconciled.

5 He hath affirmed in his Sermon, ≈øince the Arch-bi≈øhops impri≈øonment, that there were divers who ≈øought the life of the Arch-bi≈øhop, but if they did obtain it, God would require his brood at their hands.

6 The ≈øaid Dr. hath cau≈øele≈øly ≈øued and excommunicated divers poore pari≈øhioners, for that they refu≈øed to pay his pretended dues le≈øt unpaid by the former Inhabitants in their hou≈øes, enforcing them to ≈øell their hou≈øhold ≈øtuff to pay the ≈øame.

7 The ≈øaid Dr. and his Sub≈øtitutes have exacted divers ≈øummes of money for Burials & other „Äà‚óä„Äâ refu≈øing to officiate in ca≈øes of nece≈ø≈øity, without compo≈øition before hand, forcing thereby the Pari≈øhioners to bury the dead them≈øelves, & to keep their children unbaptized halfe a yeare together.

8 The ≈øaid Dr. by his conclave, or ≈øelected Ve≈øtry, exerci≈øeth tyranny over the e≈øtates and liberties of the ≈øaid Pari≈øhioners, by injurious taxing, and levying divers ≈øummes of money, ea≈øing them ≈øelves, and burd'ning others therein, di≈øpo≈øing of the principall Officers at their plea≈øure, preferring
friends and Allyes (though ≈øcandalous in life) and keeping out godly & well-affected per≈øons, under the name of Puritan's.

9 The ≈øaid Dr. Fuller hath ≈øo ill provided for this ≈øo great a Pari≈øh, that be≈øides much other di≈ø≈øervice: there having certaine Pari≈øhioners attended to ≈øee the chri≈øtian buriall of a dead corps, could neither find the ≈øaid Doctor or his Curate, though having notice before thereof: after that al≈øo, another Corps, then a third, all attending in the church yard, And at the la≈øt; hearing that Timothy Hutton his Curate, was at the Fortune to ≈øee a Play, they ≈øent to de≈øire him, to officiate for the three corps: but hee would by no meanes come; then they ≈øent a ≈øecond, and a third time al≈øo, certifying how long they had there waited: yet would the ≈øaid Timothy Hutton by no meanes come, untill ≈øuch time that the play was ended.

10 The ≈øaid Doctor Fuller hath ≈øo oppre≈øt the ≈øaid pari≈øh, by profane and ungodly per≈øons, to officiate for him, as have given very ill examples, & of dangerous con≈øequent to evill-affected people in the pari≈øh, as the ≈øaid Timothy Hutton; who hath from his pulpit repaired to the taverne on the Lords day, and there drinking uncivilly, danced and ≈øung mo≈øt profaine, & ungodly ≈øongs, & dances, to the ≈øhame and di≈øgrace of Religion, and to the griefe of many Godly people, who tooke Notice thereof.

div.head: THE HUMBLE PETITION Of divers of the Puri≈øhioners of St. Giles Cripple-Gate, London, again≈øt Timothy Hutton, Curate.
div.p:
THat on Thur≈øday, being the 15. day of October 16 ‚Ä¢ 1, at ten of the clock in the morning, Iohn Sedgwick, Batchelor in Divinity, an Orthodox Mini≈øter of the Church of England, together with a Congregation of about foure hundred per≈øons, all Pari≈øhioners of St. Giles Cripplegate, London; waited at the Church doore of St. Giles afore≈øaid, expecting the opening of the church doores, for the continuance of a weekly Lecture there; begun that day ≈øeven night by the ≈øaid Mr. Sedgwick, according to an Order of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe dated the viij. day of September la≈øt. And after one honres attendance in the raine, they were compelled to depart from the church door, being kept out, by the command of VVilliam Fuller, vicar there, Timothy Hutton his Curate, Thomas Bough, Godfrey Holmes, Samuel Taylor, Ionathan Gold≈ømith, Church-wardens, Richard Harwood, and William Guly, Sextons, all Agents for the ≈øaid vicar, Iames Andrewes, and Hutchins, pretended Clarkes of
the ≈øaid Pari≈øh: all enemies to the Reformation intended, and di≈øturbers of the peace of the ≈øaid Congregation.

This deboi≈øt Curate was taken out of the kennell drunk, at midnight, in a mo≈øt lamentable ca≈øe, & was forced by a Ju≈øtice of peace, not long ≈øince, to pay a ≈øhillings for ≈øwearing of two Oaths. His fre≈øhe≈øt Deploit was at a late Annuall Fea≈øt: whereunto being ≈øent to invite a Noble Pari≈øhioner, who gave him 20 s. to carry the Stewards, to helpe beare their Charge and expences. He deivered onely ten ≈øhillings to them, and re≈øerved the re≈øt of the money to him≈øelfe; which knavi≈øh pranke being afterwards di≈øcovered, occa≈øioned the≈øe following ver≈øes.

q.l: WHy how now Hutton, art thou grown ≈øo poore,
That thou e≈øteem'≈øt thy credit worth no mare
Then halfe a piece: me thinkes its very ≈øtrange,
That one of your Frofe≈ø≈øion ≈øhould exchange
Plaine dealing, for to get a little pelfe;
Sure you were drunke, at lea≈øt were not your ≈øelfe:
When as you wont t'invite that Noble Gue≈øt,
A bu≈øine≈ø≈øe wherewith any Porter might,
Have bin entru≈øted, and have dealt upright.
Yet you a Pulpeciere, the more's the pitty,
Wee have too many ≈øuch within the Cittie:
But He forbeare, and ≈øo conclude in few words,
Wi≈øhing the Cockney's to get better Stewards;
For thou art bafe, con≈øider of is Hutton,
Thy Credit hence forth, is not worth a Button.
